parts.text: Today is February twenty seventh two thousand and fifteen and I am interviewing him
Ilya who is the mother of Virginia model so
I want to ask you first what made you suspect that Dick Cheney was different and
what he was about twenty years old between two and
three years old I started noticing that she was a little different than other children.
In what way. Well she used to go in like a trance
. And I would call a stand in front of about three feet away
and call her and she didn't answer me and I just have to see
how long it would take her away and something that maybe in
ten minutes she'd come out of it because she'd smile in
me like she just saw me for the first time and I would ask I would
tell Oh Christian you were why you. And she would you know when she was younger she couldn't
explain too much. She would say plain.
Language doesn't play as she got older she could explain more on how
she was to say I was in a good place she says I had my friends around me
. We were talking we were laughing we were playing but she wasn't
moving she was just a drunk in a trance.
Can you tell me that the day that Cheney was diagnosed by a professional.
For the first time that I took over was because she was having trouble in school
that the teachers told me the same thing as we we call and she doesn't
answer. I stand right in front of God She doesn't even know I'm there
. And took her to a psychiatrist and he told me that
. He could only get worse or it could. You know get
better but she just seems to. Go into like these
daydreams that she's somewhere else. But it's not
normal. That you know it's not I tell the dump device but that's that's not all I
have three children and yet to one's own people.
And they didn't really put him on any medication or anything.
Twentieth to work with her to. Nap at the shake or
rather there will get angry when you know say oh we will buy you wait you know wake
up I'm calling you or something like that which I never did. She
was just so. He told me when she said hello world. She has
another world junior. And you have to accept that
That's what they told me and what class cation a disability did they get.
At that particular time they've been now told me that she could be
bipolar. Which is also bipolar and that
she could have like schizophrenia.
How would you describe your emotions. After the initial diagnosis
I you know.
I felt I don't care. Enough for myself
but for my child because she will have to go through life
with this you know with this. Disability. And
. She didn't understand it because it times
as she got older she would react to these people being around her
And these voices that she would hear. And
I was just.
Battling in how how can I bring her to understand what she
has without making her feel different than everybody else
. That. It's like maybe somebody that's not normal. That
she was as normal as anybody that she could hear things and and
see things that other people couldn't and that
she had to deal with and it's been it's been a work in progress
almost all of the life which we have pretty much under control now.
